text:
What you see on the title
slide is the environment where our manipulation
problem takes place.

So we'll be talking about this. So a little bit of
something for everyone, one of my favorite
things about robotics

is we need hardware, software,
motion planning, control, computer vision, machine
learning, manufacturing
operations, we've got it all. So here's a teaser at the start.

The task is to put inventory
onto these bookshelves, and the bookshelves are made
of a really heavy fabric

kind of a canvas so it's
a little bit flexible. We've got these mesh elastic
bands that sit-in front of those

bookshelves protecting the
items from falling out. You can see there's
a diversity of items

basically anything you
could buy on Amazon.com that's less than 20 pounds,
less than 24 inches.

They get stored
randomly, so it's not like it's all
iPhones in one shelf.

It could be a teddy
bear next to an iPhone, next to a bowling ball,
next to a light bulb. So Mark mentioned this, I
did have a whole lot of fun.

My first 15 years
as a roboticist, first here and then
at JPL, I won't

be talking about that today. I did do a Robotics
Institute seminar at Carnegie Mellon
in the fall of 2019.

And that's right when I
was making the transition, and so I actually
remembered everything cool. We were doing about ice
climbing and asteroid gripping.

And if you're really
interested in that, I encourage you to
look it up on YouTube.

So this is an Amazon warehouse. I want to talk you through
the sort of overall process

and then we'll zoom in on
the manipulation problem that we're trying to solve. Trucks basically
show up and this

is the inventory arrives step. We unload all of those items
that are not yet for sale.

We store them on those
yellow bookshelves. So break them down
singulate them, so it's a one by one process
of storing them randomly

on those bookshelves. At that point, they're
for sale on the website. And when a customer orders
one of those items, we

pick it off of
that same bookshelf try and accumulate it
with any other things that you've ordered within
the last 6 to 12 hours,

pack those into the smallest
and greenest shipping container that we can
get you your order.

And sometimes that's no
shipping container at all. I order a lot of
diapers these days. It just comes with a shipping
label on the on the diaper box.

Once those packages
are sealed, we do another sortation step to
make sure everything coming

to Stanford University
is in one truck and everything going to Menlo
Park is in a different truck. And then those trucks
go out into the network.

One thing to talk about is
there is a big supply chain that exists before this, with ports,
and boats, and factories,

and inbound cross docks. And there's a big
distribution network that happens after
this building, which

is delivery stations,
third-party carriers like Fedex and UPS, further
sortation centers.

What you see here is just
how many of these bookshelves there are. 60,000 of them in a
given fulfillment center,

there is 25 million items that
would sit on those bookshelves.

We process on good days over a
million items in a single day.
So it is a large scale problem.

With that scale comes both
opportunity and challenges, so something that's a
one in million occurrence

is a 10 or 20 times a
day thing at Amazon. So these edge cases,
the reliability,

your ability to handle those
things quickly and efficiently becomes really important. On the opportunity side, if you
want to retrain a new model,

we have massive amounts of data. So we have a package
sorting robot called Robin, that's now done
something like two or three

billion picks. And we have the kinematics
and the trajectories for all two or three
billion of those picks.

And in fact, we just
published a big dataset to make that available
to the community so that we could try and
analyze and leverage that data.

There's also because
of this scale a tremendous opportunity
to have a big impact.

So if you can deliver something,
you know it's going to go out and it's going to change the
business pretty substantially.

So let's zoom in here on stow. This is what I'll
be talking about. This is what we call
that step of putting

the items onto the bookshelf. You see a Kiva robot. That's what these guys
here are that are moving

those bookshelves around. Let's see if we can
get that to play again.

It comes to a person. So rather than a person walking
down long aisles with a shopping cart, these robots are now
bringing the bookshelves

to the people. They will scan an item and
then place it onto that shelf.

I think I've got
another video, yeah. And one of the
favorite inventions Amazon came up with a
few years ago, for me,
is she'll scan the item itself. So we get a barcode read here.

But once she places it into the
bin, there's no subsequent scan. There's a machine
learning model.

It's using a couple
of cameras that watches where the person's
hand goes into the bin and automatically
transfers that inventory

into the appropriate shelf. And that's deployed
widely at scale, so it saves a couple of
seconds on each of these stows.

And it also makes it way
more ergonomically friendly. You don't have to carry a
barcode scanner with you when you're doing this task.

Other things you might observe
when you're watching this is the workspace. So we need a ladder to
get up to the top shelves.

You've got to crouch down to
get down to the bottom shelves. We really want these warehouses
to be as dense as possible.

When you're buying a
1,000,000 square foot building outside of Tokyo or
New York City or San

Francisco, the real estate
costs, they are quite expensive, and so density is really
important to keeping the prices

low for our customers. You'll also notice she's doing
some decision-making here, so

in her head figuring out which
item will fit in which bin and how to make
space in that bin,

and when to kick that shelf
out and get a new one in that has more opportunities. So it's this kind of matching
game that you need to do.

And then the manipulation
tasks themselves-- So dealing with
those elastic bands is not trivial, making
sure that item will fit.

Especially if it's
kind of a dense fit as we're getting ready for the
Christmas season, the holiday season, these things are
getting as full to the gills

as we can get them. And so sometimes
it's pretty forceful to get stuff to fit in there.

And you've got to think
about whether you're going to damage the item. If it's a box of
batteries, you can probably

use a lot of strength. And if it's an
iPhone, maybe you want to be a little more careful.

You open those
elastic bands, grasp the item you're going to
stow, do this pre-manipulation

inside the bin to get the space
you need to stow that item, and then place the
item onto the shelf.

So we'll get pictures of
the state of those shelves, but we also have metadata on all
the other items that are already

on that shelf,
including properties like their dimensions,
the weight, we track things like
whether they're compressible

or not, whether
they're bagged or not, whether they're fragile,
liquid, lithium batteries, that kind of stuff.

We need to open
those elastic bands. So here you see a
two stow version.

Grasp the item. In this case, one of
the simplifications, we were able to do is feed
the item into the hand using

a conveyor. So there's not a lot of grass
planning, that was something we were able to get away with.

We make space in the bin using
a pretty simple manipulator, it's a piece of sheet metal
that can extend in and out.

And then we stow the item. And here, these are
actually conveyor belts that are part of our gripper.

And so we don't have to put the
entire gripper into the bin, which takes up a lot of space. We can feed that item in.

The things we care about
is, how fast can you go? We're talking about
hundreds of units per hour.

So 10-ish seconds is a good rule
of thumb to do this entire task.

Eligibility, this is a
material to be handled. So what kind of items
can you deal with?

I like to call this a
partial credit solution. So if there's a really
particularly tricky dog

toy or something like
that, we don't need to stow 100% of the inventory.

We put some thresholds and
we keep an exclusion list, so there are still
people that are doing some of those hard items.

And this is one of
those let robots do what robots are good at. Let people do those high
dexterity tasks that are maybe

still a bit in
front of the state of the art for robotics today. So our eligibility at the
moment is 70%-80% of the items,

and that's actually very good. Fullness, so how much
stuff can you fit?

GCU is Gross Cubic
Utilization, so it's sort of volumetric fullness.

Damage, we want to minimize
the number of times. We poke a hole in something
or drop something.

Amnesty is our word for
the item has left the bin, either at your station, you've
dropped it on the floor,

or you didn't get
it into the bin. And so when that Kiva robot
takes it away somewhere, as it's driving
around, it falls out.

We call that amnesty. So this is our marketing
version of the video.

I'll show you more. But what you can
see from this one is that we have a
robot arm that rides

on a seventh and eighth axis. We have a horizontal
vertical gantry. That's to grossly position
the arm either at the top row,

or bottom row, middle row. Then we have a second
robot that sits in front of that system
that's doing the elastic band

manipulation. And that's a gantry robot. We have 3 degree of
freedom and 4 degree of freedom versions of that.

You also see our end
of arm tool there, which enables the item to
be conveyed into the grasp

and then ejected into the bin
without putting that gripper in.

The bin manipulator, it's
just an extendable piece of sheet metal.

So a choice we made early
on was to break the process into two steps.

So we singulate the items
first, and then we stow them. And that enables that conveyor
feed into the gripper.

We're not trying to
pick the items out of a tote that might have
10 or 20 items in it.

That's the singulation step. And this is a philosophy
lesson, I guess. I'll get on the
soapbox for a moment.

Trying to create
a generalized, you can do everything
manipulation is crazy hard,

and you might have to wait
too long for a system that can do all of that. But if you can narrow
down the tasks,

if you can control
the environment, you can specialize
your end of arm tool, specialize your grippers.

You can control the lighting,
the sensors more directly. And this will allow you to
accomplish something earlier.

So even though, yes, it
would be desirable to have a single robot that could do
it all, by making this split,

we get something in two or three
years as opposed to 20 years. And I think this is the
same reason robotics

did so well in
manufacturing first, because that's the same task
repetitive over and over and over again so you can have
a highly specialized end of arm

tool that all it does is grip
the windshield or the rearview mirror and put it in place. We're extending that a bit.

I talk about high
clutter and high contact as the big challenges
we're trying to solve,

but it's not generalized
manipulation. So here's what that looks
like as a work cell design.

We have a singulation
step that's over here. This is shown with people. I'll show you some robots
that can do this also.

And they're fast enough
doing that singulation. Just taking the items out one
by one, doing a barcode scan,

they can feed three robots. So these people are going-- I don't know-- 1,000
units per hour.

The robots are a few
hundred units per hour. It does allow you to
mature these technologies

independently, so as soon as we
have a good singulation robot, we'll just drop it right in.

And this is one of Amazon's
singulation systems.

It's called Sparrow. So it's a pick and place task. One of the cool things about
this is all of those tags,

all of those markers
allow us to on the fly,

determine the pose of
the object in the hand because we can calibrate
off of those markers. And that enables you to
pack much more densely.

And so when you pick, you
don't know what kind of pose you're going to
get with that item. But you get it in
flight, and then you

adjust your packing
algorithm so that you can try and fill up the totes
that's going into quickly.

For us, we don't
really need that. We just need the items
one by one singulated out.

When you use suction cups
to do that kind of picking, though, really good
at certain things, like getting a credit card
off of the bottom of the bin.

Not so good if you're
trying to pick up a book. So if you lift a book with
a suction cup by the cover,

it's going to flop open. Sort of a redeeming fact
about humanity in my mind

is we still sell so many books. 7%, 8% something like
that last I checked.

So there's still some
readers out there. It's also a lot of adult
coloring books these days. We saw that go up.

So what do you do with that? There's worst cases
also maybe some things in a bag that's loose and then
you pick the bag and the item

stays behind. Or you pick a barcode sticker
that's not well attached.

In the worst case, I actually
saw it was kind of a-- I'll show examples of this.

It wasn't magic the gathering,
but it was this card game, and the robot picked the lid
of the box and then dropped it,

and then one by one picked
100 cards out of the box and then picked the
bottom of the box.

And so you need a
solution for these kind of things, where you don't have
a good surface for suction.

So these are the failure
modes, this is the blooper-- blooper reel. You don't want to
see your item getting

handled like that, right? And so I have a team
in Berlin, Germany and so we did a project looking
at two fingered grasp, which

of course is a nice compliment. I don't think of
it as an alternate. I think of as a complement to
suction, and it handles books.

It handles these things. One of the big key
unlocks for this work was predicting empty space.

So yes, we need a good 3D
representation of the world. But for pinch grasp,
we actually wanted

to have good estimates
of the occluded space that you knew you could put
your finger underneath the pile.

And so we had sort
of multiview cameras, and we're doing a signed
distance function representation

to try and predict
this grasp poses. I'll let it finish.

We got them all so this
was cherry picked video. And this is going
pretty fast as well,

so this is over
1,000 units per hour to give you a
sense of the speed.

So that's the singulation step. And I'll zoom in
a little bit more

on the stowing robots
for the rest of the talk.  One of the things I
learned at Stanford

that's been most valuable
for me is iterative design. We really embraced that in
our work cell architecture

and in our prototyping methods. So we started with
really simple stuff.

This is aluminum extrusion. This thing was cantilevered. It would wave back and
forth at like 1 or 2 hertz.

We used blender to really
visualize the workspace. But the value of
doing this prototyping

is that you really understand
your problem a lot better. It also gave the motion planning
and computer vision teams

some early test beds to
start development on. And we knew that we
were going to iterate.

And so once we got
something that we liked, we built a hardened version. And this is in a
fulfillment center.

It's in a warehouse. That's a test warehouse. And so it's processing
live orders.

We get to exposure to
all the variety of items and bin conditions
and edge cases.

But there's always
a backup plan. So when inevitably the
robot goes down for a day

if you're lucky, or a
week if it's tricky, it's not like 5,000 people don't
get their birthday presents

in Redwood City. And so we've been doing
this for about a year. We've got 100,000
stows or something

like that in this
test environment. And then I'm very excited. We just launched in
Spokane, Washington

at a Live FC, a
prototype of this that will work through
the Christmas season

and give us real data. It's not a test
environment anymore. This is our first foray
into truly the real world.

We also iterate of course
on the pieces of the system. So the elastic band separation--

One of the interesting
failure modes-- I don't know if any of you
caught this in your head. When we open the bands and
pull some of them down,

we will trap sometimes an item
against the floor of the bin. So imagine like a
T-shirt in a bag.

You may pin the bag on
the floor of the bin. Now I try and sweep it to the
side, and I'm fighting myself,

or I'm ripping that bag open. And so we moved on-- I don't know if this video-- I think, yeah, to
more of a hook design,

working on both the mechanical
design of that, as well as the motions. We do have for sensing
in the loop on this,

so we can plan those motions
not just based on waypoints but also based on contact
and things like that.

We continued this
work, and I really wanted to show these
videos because they were

made by some of our interns. And so we had a pretty
good success rate, but sometimes the top
band would slip off.

We also had this bin lip, the
fabric lip along the bottom of that bookshelf. It's fairly stiff, and if you're
trying to stow a tall item

you either have to twist the
item to get around that bin lip or otherwise deal with it.

And so our interns set out to
build better mechanical systems and build better motions.

And this is what they
came up, with using the UR robots as a test bed. And now we can fuse
those into our work,

now that we have data
that gives us confidence in their performance.

We also have design iteration
in the gripper itself. So we really followed that
IDO brainstorming process.

We went for volume. We spent a good couple of weeks
coming up with every concept

we could think of, yes
and, not, no, because. We filtered those
through a set of criteria

and prototyped three
or four of them using literally popsicle sticks
and styrofoam and things.

This was right peak pandemic. And so we were
doing this sometimes in our home with cereal
boxes in the pantry.

And once we got something
we liked, we matured it. And so we picked this
style, these two plates,

and we call it a panini gripper. I hope that is obvious why. We liked that because you have
6DOF pose control of the item.

So if you have a
two-finger gripper and you've got a T-shirt, it's
going to be flopping around. You're not able to control
that precisely as you try

and stow it. The other reason we
really liked it is you have a known engineering
surface that you're

making contact with the world,
which is the back of the paddle. So rather than trying to
push with a book on one stow

and then push with a
T-shirt on the next stow and then push with a teddy
bear and then a bowling ball, we have this at least one side
of the contact is well-modeled,

well-understood. And that evolved into a
special bin manipulator, this piece of sheet metal.

And in V1, that was
kind of a fruit ninja, it would rotate and chop down.

And then it became more
of like a wolverine style, where it would extend
out from inside the hand.

The latest thing we've done here
is move the force torque sensor from the wrist out
to that paddle,

so that we don't
have all the inertia and losses of this
end of arm tool

that's a couple of kilograms. And that's actually really
improved our control bandwidth.

So here's what that Looks. Next steps of course
also are some design for manufacturing, some cost
engineering, things like that.

One of the other things
I'm proud of with this work is on the electrical side.

So Amazon and most warehouse
robotics, industrial robotics folks are using system
integration techniques,

and so you have a big electrical
cabinet with servo drives that cost 500% of what
you think they should

cost if you've taken to 18. And you run all
these cables that are way bigger and stiffer
than you might need them to be.

And so with four servo motors,
and four torque sensors, and limit switches, I think
we were up to 15 or 16 cables

in this enormous,
fire-hose-like dress pack. And as you're trying
to do compliant control

and you've got a 10 pounds
cable flopping around, I can tell you that
generated a lot of noise that

was affecting our
ability to understand what was happening between
the gripper and the items.

So we built our
own embedded board with some of those
motor drivers. We're using EtherCat
as a protocol.

So found some EtherCat
servo drivers. And now we have
single connector, we're down to five conductors,
I think, from 64 and 15 cables.

So this is the other
thing iteration gets you. If I shift to the robotic
science side of the problem,

there's two primary areas
I like to talk about.

One is compliant control. So adding that force and
torque in the loop signal,

high bandwidth couple 100
hertz in that control loop. And then the second is
the decision-making.

So we definitely need a good
3D representation of the scene.

So the computer vision
piece is foundational, but that's not enough. So it's not a peg
and hole problem

because the hole is
not always there. We have to create the hole. And so you have to reason
over that 3D representation

of the scene and
predict where you might be able to make
space if you were to do some of these motions.

So you have to create the
hole and then your peg is shaped like an Amazon item,
which, again, is teddy bear,

and then bowling ball,
and then USB stick. So I'll talk about
each of these. We have other robotics
science that we leverage,

so a lot of free-space
motion planning. But here we're not
really trying to invent. We're trying to capture what's
already state of the art.

And so we do KOMO formulations
for our free-space motion

planning which is from Mark
Toussaint over in TU Berlin. We've also done some
of the techniques that Russ Tedrake out
at MIT has put forward.

We are also running
always a recovery plan so that when we don't
make enough room

and we think we can sweep 10
centimeters, but we were wrong and we only get six and the
item in our hand is too big,

we want to have an immediate
way to recycle that item. So at Amazon, those
seconds count,

and so having to wait
there to recalculate your recovery trajectory
is costs a lot of money.

When we think about the
first science challenge where I would say we're
doing some of this invention

that force and torque
in the loop control, we've experimented with
impedance style controllers

with torque sensing at
each joint, torque control at each joint in the robot arm. And we've also played around
with admittance controllers,

where we are only using
the force torque sensing at the wrist, or even now
further out at the blade.

And we landed on the admittance
side of this classic debate because the contact is always
occurring through that blade.

It's never the case
in our application where the elbow of the robot
is getting into contact

nor are we able to
generate a good model. So our impedance
controllers would

fail because we would
pick up an item that would have unknown or not
well-modeled mass properties

and then we weren't able to
keep a good model of the robot updated. So I think in the long
run, it's maybe more ideal,

but we found the
admittance control was really practical and
viable for our application.

Another simplification that
made this a tractable problem was not trying to imagine
any motion under the sun.

We have canonical
motion primitives, and so it collapses to a problem
of picking which primitive

and which initial
conditions to use as opposed to trying to come up with a
new strategy on every bin.

And so we have these four
primitives-- slot wedge, really is the
pigeonhole problem. There's empty space
or it's an empty bin,

just go chuck an
item into that bin. Stacking is sort of similar,
you have an empty space.

But we are reasoning about the
stability of that pile using surface normals to
decide whether or not

it's going to stay
there or fall out later. Bin sweeps are probably
the most common. Here you might have a
stack of library books

that is fallen over, or a bunch
of discrete items with spaces in between we insert
that sheet metal blade

and then push
everything to the side to consolidate the
available space, even compressing
sometimes those items that

are T-shirts or other
things that are not harmed by being squeezed.

Probably the most
fun is flip up. So here's where a book has
fallen over flat in the bin.

You don't want to create a pile. That actually makes it
harder for the people that have to pick the items out.

If you're trying to get the
book off the bottom of the pile, it's way worse than
getting the book out of the middle of
the library shelf.

And so we put that blade
underneath the item and then rotate
it up to the side. And there are variants of these.

It's more of a spectrum than
really for discrete points. But I'll show you videos.

So here's slot wedge. Again, this is the easiest
empty bin or empty space. Take the item and put it in.

In fact, now we
make a calculation about whether we even need to
extend that sheet metal blade. It's an empty bin.

Just aim for the middle
and go as fast as you can.

For stacking, we have
methods where we actually use that blade to push
down the elastic bands so

that the pile won't
fall out, or we have a lower
probability of the item that we're putting in
the bin to fall out.

But we're essentially
inserting things on top. What I'm not showing is some of
the surface normal calculations that we've done recently.

This is an ugly pile. We generally would not want
to stack an entire bin. We'd want to put one item on
top only when it's very dense.

This is actually
a knob that they turn on and off in operation. So during the nine months
of the year before now,

they're like, any way possible,
get those bins as full as you can. So from a robotic perspective,
we can also turn that on and off
depending on conditions. So here are bin sweeps.

And this is interesting
because there's more steps in the process. So we're indexing.

We touch the item
there to index off of before moving to the
wall of the bookshelf

to do the full blade insertion. And that takes out
some of the error. Your perception system might
have 1 or 2 centimeters

of stacked up error. And so that's too much to have a
high reliability blade insertion

in these dense bins. And so we'll do the same thing
a human does when they're picking up a coin off
of a table rather than

trying to go precisely
to the spot in space where you can grasp that coin. You go to a reference,
make contact,

and then slide
along that contact until you can
accomplish the task.

You'll see different
strategies here, sometimes we're inserting
the blade above the items and kind of sweeping down.

Sometimes we're
seeking out that wall. That's the fabric wall. And sometimes we are just
going into empty space

where we have confidence
that there's not going to be a collision of the blade.

You can see this is
with the old gripper. If you look closely,
there is this nasty bundle of cables that are on the back.

And one of the other interesting
things I think from a science perspective that we're doing
is when we stow to the same bin

multiple times, we use memory. So we know how
much space we were able to create when
we did the sweep.

And so you can use that rather
than your perception output, because you have now a
ground truth measurement.

You can use that to update
the bin item match, as well as the kinds of motion
primitives that you might use.
So here's flip up.

We're also, again, trying
to make these fast, and so that's a challenge.

That's why you want that really
clean force torque signal because you don't want to
sit there and filter it
for a long time.

Yeah. So I'm going to switch over to
the other science problem now, which is the decision-making.

And so the seed of that
is the computer vision. Here we also took an
iterative approach.

So it's the same
principles, whether you're in hardware or software. We started with
something simple,

which is an occupancy map. Basically, it's a
yellow/not yellow model.

When the bookshelf
is all yellow, that's what it's learning. We also had an elastic
band segmentation mask

so we know where
to put in that hook to lift the elastic
bands out of the way.

We evolved this pretty quickly. And so the logical next step
of course is segmentation.

And we've actually got
instant segmentation, we're actually
labeling the items now, sometimes we're
able to tell which

item it is based on
dimensions or color RGB embeddings that kind of thing.

And so we will use
that to determine whether we can compress the
stack or not, for instance.

We would really love to have
some depth information that would help you. We are confounded by
those elastic bands.

So the traditional
techniques, just use a lidar. Projected light
pattern, these don't

work well at all because you
get all these false returns from the elastic bands. And so what our team
is doing instead

is trying to infer depth
from monocular images. So the problem is
fairly structured,

we can collect ground truth
data with those kind of lidars and other active sensors
when the bands are removed,

and then compare them to
the 2D images we have. And because of the
structure of the problem, we can actually get a fairly
good inferred depth model.

We can also use simulation. So that's what's shown here. That gives you
ground truth really easily, lets you build up
a backbone of your model,

and then you augment it with
some real data from the field.

The other thing we do to deal
with those elastic bands, we have something
called blind inpainting. So some of your cell
phones have this.

If you have someone
who's photobombed you, you can magic eraser them out.

Same techniques here to
hallucinate the pixels behind the elastic bands.

And if we do this as
a pre-processing step before the segmentation,
we do get better results.

Again, works pretty
well because our domain is fairly well-defined. So this is again that
difference between a general

works everywhere
in the wild problem and how to structure
your system so automation
will have a good chance.

Yaw and perspective-- This
was the one that surprised me. I thought we would be able
to geometrically handle this,

but it turns out it's a lot
harder than we initially thought. It's challenging because
both the floor of the bin

and the wall of the bin or
that same yellow fabric. So your camera has a
hard time determining,

especially when that
floor might have a curvature because its fabric. The other problem
here is the item

might be pushed all the way back
against the back of the bin, or it may be way
up at the front. And if you have a box, it could
be sitting perfectly square

or it could be yawed. And so in your 2D
image, you may have some bin that looks like
it's completely full.

Your manifest says it
should be a quarter full, and it's because that item
is rotated in the bin.

And so we've done a lot
of work to try and correct for that perspective error and
do orthographic reprojection

to accommodate the angle
that you're looking out at the edges of the outer bins.

So this is still
work in progress. But for the computer
vision folks in the room if you have ideas,
this is my solicitation.

Another improvement
we made was labeling every pixel in the scene. And some of this is useful
like that bin lip understanding

where that bin lip is. You can change your strategy. Also we have these metal bars
that are the frame of the pod.

And obviously, you get
a different response if you sweep your bin
manipulator into the metal bar

than you do if you
are pushing a T-shirt. And so knowing
where those are also gives us better performance.

And so this was a step up. And now, we've moved
on to infer depth

from stereo, which I know
sounds a little weird, you generally think
you're going to do dense stereo geometrically.

But we're actually taking
the stereo as inputs and then training a model
again using that ground truth

depth sensing because
of the elastic bands.

So when we try to make a
decision about which of the 30 or 40 items that
are available to us

should go into which
of the 25 or 30 bins are on the
bookshelf in front of us,

we currently have a decision
tree that some of those leafs have a little bit of ML in them.

But it's at the highest level. It's a one size fits all. So we're not
adjusting that model

for when we have a 1 pound item
versus a 1 ounce item versus a 5 pounds item. We're not adjusting
it for when the bin is

super full versus pretty empty. And so we've engaged in
some work with a professor

so that we can have more
tailored motions depending on the bin state and depending
on the item that we're stowing.

The other thing
that we like to do is a good example of
the value of this work is you might want to stow the
first six items that you can

fit into the bin
face using a fairly conservative set of rules. But when you're ready to kick
out that pod, when you say,

I can't stow any more,
that's the time when you should take risk. That's the time when you
might want to say, well,

I have 88% confidence or
92% confidence in this stow. Now you can do an assessment
of the time penalty

it's going to cost if you
fail, versus the extra stow-- the value you get from that.

And so Lillian is working on
this, it's super exciting. So this is my penultimate slide.

What I hope you take away from
